I did find two candles shaped like pinecones that I had been given by a nurse who believes in the literal, and we lit them ceremonially and made the kitchen look like a church for trees.

In the softened dark, Liina’s labels became talismans. Chair glowed like an incantation. Window became a question mark. Rosemary looked theatrical, its needles points more points in the flicker. We did not speak at first because you do not ask the dark to hurry. When we did talk, it was the way people in boats talk when they are not afraid of being heard by the water. Liina picked up the marker and wrote small signs for things we had not named because we had believed they would name themselves forever. Silence. Breath. Patience. She stuck Patience to my shoulder and I laughed enough to make the candles wobble. “Tell me one small lie,” she said, later, because asking for honesty would have been disrespectful to the theatre of the evening, and I said, after carefully thinking about truths that wouldn’t be offended, “I don’t worry about anything before bed,” and she accepted the lie with a solemn nod and returned the favor with, “I never double-knot my scarf.”

She stood by the window with her hands on the sill and looked at the black glass and our reflections and the small fire inside the candles. “When the hum stops,” she said after a while, “I can hear other hums. The inside ones. The good ones. The ones that are like cats lying on your knees,” and her voice was almost apologetic for having become more than conversation for a moment. “Do you hear yours?” I asked, and she tilted her head and listened with that scientist’s patience she has when she is being kind to herself. “Yes,” she said, “and something else,” and she touched the inside of her wrist lightly, and I knew better than to ask. The seam was not brighter in candlelight, only more itself. When the power came back at last with that ungraceful cough of everyday life restarting and the fridge shuddered as if waking with a headache, we both sighed and pretended to be relieved. We blew the candles out together and watched the smoke curl, and it smelled exactly like kitchens everywhere pretending to be forests.

At work, our ward had a new patient whose diagnosis had the neat ring of names people carry reluctantly. Korsakoff was there in the notes like a distant cousin you hope won’t drink too much at the wedding. The man had a good face for stories, and he made his way through the day with an invented dignity and an invented calendar. He told me he owned three clocks and none of them were wrong, and I believed him for the sake of our conversation. He called Salla Miss twice and then apologized the third time, and Salla, who knows how to be the person you need and the person you have, told him that Miss was a rank she had earned with perseverance. He asked me, very softly, as if talking to a cat under a bed, what day it was, and when I told him, he looked relieved, like he had been afraid it was his birthday. “Dates stick like burrs,” he said gravely, and then asked me if I had ever seen a star explode. “Only the ones that never thought of themselves as stars,” I said, and made a note to check his thiamine.

Eero, the junior doctor with good shoulders and better metaphors, caught me at the end of the corridor with a question shaped like a statement. “Your neighbor,” he said, and watched my face carefully as if he were reading a tide chart. “How is she today?” I told him she had written the word hunger on the fridge and seemed very pleased with the placement. He nodded like this satisfied the part of him that reads papers and the part that goes home to a plant he waters too much. “Memory’s not a shelf you knock dust off once and declare clean,” he said, and I wanted to be annoyed at the metaphor and instead pocketed it because it will be useful again. There are days when you can swallow only so many analogies before you start to prefer numbers, but this was not one of them.

In the evenings, our rooms multiplied. She made a box labeled Tram with a bell as precise as the bell could be in the mind, a little plaque that said “Pyynikintori” in letters so small I wanted to pick them up with tweezers. She made a box labeled Stairwell and it contained a banister with the exact worn spot where everyone puts their hand when they decide to turn back because they have forgotten their keys. I made a box of my own one night because love is sometimes imitation without warning. My hands are not practiced the way hers are, but I cut cardboard and glued quietly and made a room almost exactly like the break room at the hospital, including the burnt mark in the microwave and the distant view through a window no one opened. When I showed it to her, I did so with the bravado of a boy showing a half-carved boat to a master shipwright, and she did not laugh. She held it like her boxes held her, with equilibrium and gratitude and that curious way of turning things under the light as if they had hidden genders. “You put the wrong chair next to the window,” she said gently, and I looked and laughed because she was right, and we changed it together, and the rightness was a physical thing, a click I could feel in my elbow.

One morning, there was a knock on her door that belonged to someone who had rehearsed it. Not a neighbor’s polite bullet, not the building’s habitual shrug, but a sequence like a practiced finger exercise on a piano: two, then two, then one. Liina stood very still in the space between kitchen and hall, and I watched something like weather pass across her face—sun, cloud, mist, the possibility of thunder. I opened the door because being the person who opens doors had become one of my roles. A man stood there who wore the coast like a light scarf, not obviously, not deliberately, but a suggestion of salt and a squint you earned mapping wind. He was the kind of man who has learned to be silent in company because his voice would always be the loudest thing in a room if he let it. He held his hands folded in front of him, empty, the way good men do when they want to show that they know they are arriving uninvited.

“Do you know a Liina?” he asked me, but shorter, as if conserving words in case he needed them later. His Finnish was enough and his accent did the small dance that tells you there is another language sleeping behind the teeth. I turned slightly so that he could see her over my shoulder. He did not flinch and he did not smile. He took a breath as if he were about to dive for something he had dropped long ago. “I’m not here to take,” he said to the air in front of him in case anyone would think of asking him to prove it. “I’m here to say a name. I have kept it for a while and it is heavy,” and I stood aside the way you stand aside for a person carrying furniture. Liina’s shoulders arranged themselves into a posture I had not seen since before the ferry, a straightness like a spar, not defiant, not hiding; the body remembers being a mast even if the sails were never hers.

He took off his hat and offered his head the same way you offer your hands; I noticed he had a scar above his eyebrow that had decided long ago to be a decorative line. “I call you Helmi,” he said, softly, and the room did the small tilt it does when you realize the table is not where you thought it was; something inside me reached immediately for a polite answer and caught only air. The name hung in the kitchen like a coat no one had expected to see again. Liina did not reach for it. She stood very still and then turned her head one degree as if that would help the name come into focus. “I am Liina,” she said after a time appropriate to the situation, and the man nodded as if he had been prepared for this possibility, as if somewhere a printed version of the day had contained that line already. “Yes,” he said, and the word had two meanings and he allowed both. “But also once you were Helmi.” The simplicity was a kindness I had not thought of.

We sat because sitting makes truth smaller. The man, who called himself Arto as if his name were a tool he expected to lend, did not make a big show of anything: not gratitude, not grief, not authority. He told us about a town that was more wind than map, about a house on the edge of a stubbled field where women came to drink coffee at odd hours, about a workshop that had too many jars and not enough answers, about a girl who ran along the harbor with her hand out to touch the rails of boats as if the feel of the metal would turn into a set of instructions she could follow later. He did not say brother, he did not say husband, he did not say father. He said we as if he believed in the first person plural only as a form of penance. Liina listened like a person who has stumbled upon a choir rehearsing in a church she did not enter on purpose. When he used the name Helmi, it fell into the room with a respectful weight; when he used the name Liina because she used it first, it made a different sound that was not unkind.

“What do you want me to remember?” Liina asked when he paused, that gentle way she has of not flinching while also not surrendering, and he shook his head once, firmly, like a man refusing an extra jacket. “Nothing,” he said, and then added, as if he had already rehearsed the second sentence and would be punished for forgetting it, “Only that you were loved in a house where the roof leaked, and that you always stood at the edge of things and counted to a number we did not know.” He set a small object on the table between us then, a habit we had cultivated too—objects as arguments, as apologies, as proof of something the mouth cannot yet handle. It was a button, old, mother-of-pearl, its back threaded with a tiny twist of wire, the sort of thing you would keep in a jar for a long time because you are sure it will one day be exactly the one you need. Liina touched it with one finger and breathed out. “I like buttons,” she said in a tone that could have been this morning or ten years ago, and Arto nodded once and stood as if he had finished something and was not sure what to do with his hands now that they were empty again.

He did not stay. He did not say he would return. He said thank you to the surface of the table and then to the doorway and then to me and then to the building without looking at any of us too directly, and when he left, the stairwell took him with its hum the way the city knows how to absorb the arriving and the departing without keeping a list. We stood in the quiet he left the way you stand in a room after moving a heavy piece of furniture, that searching the air for the shape that is missing and for the new space where you could dance if you were a different kind of person. Liina did not speak for longer than was comfortable. I learned in those months to let discomfort be a room we occupied without rearranging chairs. When she did speak, she used my name as if it were a lantern. “Urse,” she said, and my breath, which had been doing something unhelpful, remembered its training. “We can be many names and only one person,” she added, and I believed her because she said it without needing me to.

That night she did something she had not done since before the water: she put people in a box. It was small and the figures were only suggested, wire and paper and a smear of paint, not faces, not hands, but the bend of a spine that said waiting, the angle of a head that said listening, the slope of shoulders under a coat that said leaving held in tension with staying. The room in the box was a narrow kitchen with a window like hers and a table like mine and a bowl like every bowl that has ever held soup in an emergency. The two figures did not touch. They were placed close enough to seem arranged but far enough to keep a small honest loneliness between them. She set the box on the table and we adjusted the lamp until the light fell as if it were morning. “We are allowed to do this once,” she said in a voice that did not ask permission from any god I know, and I nodded, as if I had been around when the rule about empty rooms was made and had signed the exception with my own hand.

There came a day when the seam at her wrist looked less like a seam and more like a road on a child’s atlas, a pale path that meant moving and not dividing, and I wondered if all our looking had changed its purpose. We did not stop wondering out loud about it. “If this is a place where the map folds,” she said, sipping tea that had gone lukewarm and refusing to scold it, “I would like to see the other side,” and I told her that even if it was just a trick of winter, it was ours. She sometimes held her hand up in the bathroom mirror and turned it gently one way and then the other, watching the light catch on that ridge, and I would walk past and think: we are all made of joints and hinges and a faith in screws, and there is no shame in tightening what has loosened.

The day after Arto’s visit, Mira at the hospital front desk wore both earrings and the smile of someone whose life has recently obeyed her. She slid a small envelope across the counter to me without looking up from her computer, the way a magician guides you toward the card you were going to pick anyway. My name was on it in a hand I did not recognize and inside were two tickets from a month ago, for a ferry we had ridden, and a note, in straight, unfamiliar block letters, that said, Keep these. Proof you began. I stood there with the ugly light of the lobby on my face and thought about souvenirs and receipts and the rich archive of pieces of paper that tell us what we did long after our minds have decided to do triage. I took the tickets home and stuck them under the magnet with the fish with the gap in its tail, and that night, when Liina came in with her hair wet from a shower and the sleeves of her sweater rolled up as if work were waiting, she stood in front of the tickets and read the small print. “Proof we began,” she repeated, and looked over her shoulder at me with an expression I wish I could fold and keep in my pocket, something like agreement delivered by a choir of witnesses.

We still had not been back to the coast and we did not hurry to be there. It would wait. It has been waiting for all of us for longer than anyone agreed to count. We made instead a habit of small waters. The sinks. The kettles. The glasses left with a ring on the table that could be traced as a geography lesson. The sink in the hospital with its high lip and old-fashioned taps. The rain gutter outside Salla’s apartment that had learned to sing one note. The ink water where she cleaned her brush when the box she was making required a shadow under a chair. We washed the lemons before we sliced them as if delicacy required ritual. She put the worthless little metal piece back into a jar where it belonged, and when she shook the jar gently it sounded like its own weather. In those weeks I learned how to hold my breath to listen to something that did not need my oxygen. There is a keeping that is not grabbing, and there is a love that is mostly permission.

In bed sometimes, half asleep, she would roll toward me with the carefulness of a person docking a boat, and she would set her hand on my collarbone and tap a small rhythm there that I came to call the good hum, and I would close my eyes and say my name twice, and then hers, once, twice, and then Helmi under my breath out of respect and then back to Liina, and the names would stack and settle into a shape we could sleep inside. Spring, against its habitual reluctance, came on more quickly after that. The buses were less late. The mornings were pewter for fewer hours at a time. The neighbor tuned his bicycle in the hall and whistled a piece of a polka he never finished. Salla brought me a bouquet of parsley and a warning that she would set me up on a blind date if I did not behave, then looked at my face and took it back without regret. Jarmo made an honest joke and we all forgave him for keeping his heart in his desk.

On a Sunday that felt like it had been released early for good behavior, we went to the flea market not for anything but for the practice of wanting and not taking. Liina found a clock without hands and held it up to her ear, and I said, because I cannot help myself, “It is telling the truth,” and she grinned and put it back as if we had both been given permission to leave some truths where we found them. We bought a small drawer with many little compartments because that is the sort of thing you buy, and we carried it home between us like a heavy secret, and we filled it with labels that were not objects but ideas. Forgive. Begin. Return. Learn. Lose. Keep. We argued brief, wonderful arguments about placement. We compromised without injury. We wrote names on paper until the pen tired. It is a luxury to build a life in pieces and then pretend it came like this, whole, a single gesture, a hand closed and then opened over a table so that everything falls where it should. We did not have that luxury and we did not want it. We had the good work of choosing, and the better work of choosing again.

Chapter 7 was the week the city finally unlaced its boots and set them to dry on the radiator, a damp resignation in the air and the smell of sidewalks letting go. The snow at the curb lifted its hem and showed gray ankles; at crossing lights, people’s faces softened into the faces they wear for ordinary weather. The lemon tree took on a confidence I hadn’t seen before, small polished suns nudging their way further into our conversations, and the rosemary, stubborn icon that it is, held its shape as if winter had been a rumor. On the fridge, our drawer of verbs had become a map for how to walk through a day, and I found I was reading it without thinking as if someone had posted the tram schedule inside my chest. I wanted very much to choose Return with a decisive fingertip and stick it somewhere the decision would hear itself and obey. Throughout the week, the idea of going back to the coast hovered like steam over tea, a presence you could ignore only if you were determined to drink cold. When I came home with a bag of potatoes and the latest hospital gossip, Liina was arranging the tiny benches in a new box marked Waiting Room with an accuracy that felt like a charm; she tilted the clock on the cardboard wall twice to get the angle of perpetually-wrong right, and when I said the word Return aloud just to test the temperature of it in the room, she glanced up and held me with that steady cataloger’s gaze. “Let’s go while the sea is still half-winter,” she said, and the certainty in her voice brought the rest of my sentence into the world without my help.

Salla stood with me in the stairwell the next morning, her hands full of paper tulips for the nurses’ station because there are people whose work is to insert spring into hospitals by force. She listened while I told her we were taking a few days to go to the coast, and she made that face she makes when she approves but doesn’t want me getting proud. “Pack wool and permission,” she said, threading a green paper stem through a loop she’d made with her ring finger, and then added, with the practical mercy of someone who has watched more than one friend throw themselves against time, “and bring me back a rock that looks like a potato.” Jarmo overheard and lifted his eyebrows in the universal gesture for I will complain in the absence of your competence but only to keep my reputation, and I promised him a postcard and he promised to not read it. Eero, leaning on the counter with a chart he had taken hostage, said something about fog as a brain’s hobby and then made himself more useful by finding me a train timetable that had the audacity to claim the world ran at hourly intervals. I wrote our plan on my hand in block letters though it lived three times over in my phone; for reasons I did not need to justify, ink on skin felt more trustworthy than pixels.

We took the early train on a Friday that already smelled like a Saturday, carrying bread wrapped in paper and a thermos that sweated on my knee. The car was full of people who travel like professionals, hands that know which strap to hold, eyes that half-close for miles, and we made ourselves small among them the way you do when you try not to disturb a large animal lying down. Past Lempäälä, the fields made their habitual argument for restraint, lines of birch standing like a jury. Liina sat with her cheek on the cold of the window for so long that a pale oval appeared there, and when she pulled away a little, she smiled at the mark her face had made as if she’d been able to leave a small version of herself riding outward for the parts that would need reminding later. We did not talk much, and when we did it was in the present tense, careful declarations that belonged to train hours. There is a kindness in speaking only as far as you can see.

Arto had not promised to meet us and we had not asked him to. We did not call to warn any town of our arrival. We walked out of the station with our small bag, and the wind met us like an acquaintance who has long memories and a limited tolerance for performance. The smell of salt and old rope and diesel was a language even people born inland can learn to conjugate. Turku did its sensible practical bustle around us, and we walked to the river because that is how you greet the city without making it self-conscious. Boats hunched at their moorings like horses shouldering into winter; a gull landed on a railing with the satisfaction of a person reaching their stop in time to get the good seat. Liina’s hand found mine the way it had learned to do in rooms, and we both breathed as if we were trying to speak at once and had decided to begin with inhalation.

We took a bus that swayed the way buses sway when they are not pretending to be trains, and then another that clearly only existed for people who already knew it existed, and we got off because the driver nodded to us in a way that felt like a lesson being offered. The town was more wind than map, just like Arto had promised without promising. Houses sat as if they were trying their best to look as if they had been born there and had stayed, color beaten from their boards into something respectable. A dog with an old man’s face looked at us then considered its next nap; a woman carrying a bag of potatoes moved with the certainty of someone who can make three days of food from almost anything. We stood for a moment just inside the town as if testing water with our ankles. “Listen,” Liina said, and there it was under everything—waves slapping something wooden, that particular sound that can be praise or a correction issued without rancor. We followed it the way children follow music.

The house we found by not looking for it. It was the sort of house that is no longer a metaphor when someone says the roof leaks; you could see the place where the shingles had given up in a long sigh. There were jars in the window with the ghosts of their labels rubbed so thin you could see the hands that had held them through the glass. The doormat was the kind that remembers shoes and seasons; a boot scrape of iron stood like an elder on the step. Liina stopped a meter from the door, and her shoulders squared in that way I had learned to love, that way of making yourself into an instrument tuned for both kindness and weather. She did not touch the handle. She lifted her hand and placed it against the wood as if listening for blood through a door’s chest. Inside, someone moved with the particular sound of someone who knows where the squeaks are and chooses to avoid them. The door opened before we knocked; a woman stood there who could have been anyone’s aunt or everyone’s neighbor, her hair tucked into a scarf in a way that meant work, not fashion, her eyes withheld only as much as made sense. She looked at me and then at Liina and then at the air between us, and her mouth did a small thing that was not smile and not grimace and not shock and not relief. “You came in the right season,” she said, as if that were the only test the town required.

She led us in without asking for our names like the past can be introduced later. The kitchen was the kitchen of all winters, and the first thing she did was put water on to boil because that is how people take each other’s temperature here. The jars in the workshop were visible through a half door, and the sound of tiny screws being convincingly themselves made the hair at my forearms lift. The woman did not tell us her name until we sat, and when she did she said it low, a way of keeping it for herself even as she gave it. “Aila,” she offered, and she pressed her thumb into the table as if to anchor herself to that version of the day. She called into the other room a name that was not a person’s but the work itself, “Kädet,” hands, as if summoning them from where they were busy, and a second later Arto appeared wiping nothing from his fingers the way men do when they are watching their words and pretending to clean them.

We did not exchange formalities because the room had already introduced us. Aila set cups on the table and did the small scolding singing of someone who insists you take the first and last pieces of bread as a test of character. The tea tasted like leaves that had been asked to please wake up and did. Liina looked at the wall and then at the clock and then at the corner of the floor near the stove, that place where ash makes a fine habit, and she startled me by reaching down and brushing her fingers along the molding like someone reading a name carved there once on a dare. “It was a mouse,” Aila said, without apology, because some things are simply facts and we honor each other by telling them. We ate soup with a honesty that made conversation unnecessary for several minutes. Soup that had been made with onions and potatoes and the kind of meat you talk to before putting it in the pot, and the thyme in it made me look at my pocket for the tiny vial as if it might have traveled of its own accord.

After we ate, Arto stood and made the small gesture that allows someone to follow without losing face. The workshop was the sort of room that makes order out of a thousand small disobediences. Jars of screws and washers and nuts lined the wall in ranks, each with their chalk label in a hand like mine and like Liina’s, straight, uncompromised by flourish. A calendar from three years ago had been tacked above the bench, not because no new calendar existed but because the photograph at the top was the right photograph—the ferry caught in a glare that made its edges less sharp. There was a clock without a face suspended from a nail, its innards revealed like a lesson. A tiny metal bird with a copper beak sat in a tin dish as if recovering from a wet day. Liina stepped into the room and paused as if waiting for her body to lurch forward in recognition. When it didn’t, she took an ordinary breath and then moved to the bench and picked up a jar and shook it once with that reverent motion that made rain out of whatever was inside. The agreeability of screws poured over their own kind made her eyes close for a blink that lasted a fraction longer than mine.

Arto watched her like someone watching a shore for a tide they have learned not to predict. “We didn’t keep your things, Helmi,” he said, and then quickly offered, “Liina,” because we were in the present and he could feel my breath sharpen. “Things do not stay in houses like this. They go on. They become useful elsewhere,” and he gestured with his chin toward the jars as if those jars had once been a grammar book, a coat, a child. He did not offer us a story and pretend it was the only one available. He set a small wooden box on the bench with both hands, the way you set something living down, and stood back. Its lid had a hairline split running across it like a question mark stretched too far; the hinge creaked a little in a friendly voice. Inside there were buttons, the sort you find in flea market bowls and choose not because they match but because they remember. There was a wooden spool with the last turn of green thread clinging, and two rusty hooks, and three nails that had given up their points in some past argument with wood, and at the bottom, a strip of fabric with a small bright pattern like strawberries that had been washed into strawberries’ ghosts. Liina lifted the fabric and held it so that the window light could prove it was thin. “You liked to keep the wrong things,” Aila said from the doorway, not unkind. “You liked to say you would know when they were right again.”

The sound of the sea through the workshop wall was a constant like a memory someone else hummed under their breath. The men in town will tell you they do not hear it anymore, and then they will describe the difference between a south wind slap and a nor’east’s slow bully and call themselves liars without shame. Liina turned her wrist over and, almost idly, touched the seam there with her thumb, not pressing, not tracing, just acknowledging that it still belonged to her. Arto’s eyes flicked to the motion and then away as if to spare her the weight of being looked at too closely. He lifted a small device from a shelf, something between a toy and a tool, gears inside a glass dome no bigger than an egg, a spring that remembered more patience than I can claim. “You brought me this once,” he said, setting it where the light would find it without our help. “You found it in a box marked Break and you wanted me to teach you how to make it either run or stop. You said both were holy.” He put the key to the spring in her palm and waited. She held it like someone holds a stranger’s child, ready to learn the weight first. Then, slowly, she set the key into the slit and turned until the spring made that tight sound that can be greed or anticipation depending on your faith. The little gears moved, and a copper tongue lifted and fell with a rhythm near to heart’s; the dome fogged a little where her breath touched it and cleared as if what was inside was deciduous.

“Did I know how to fix things?” she asked after a time, eyes on the small moving world on the bench, and Arto laughed in the kind way that is not at anyone, not even at himself. “You knew how to make the table clean enough for me to try,” he said, and then, with a softness that made the room want to lean in, “and you knew how to tell when a thing would never be itself again, and you were kinder to those things than I was.” Aila came behind him and reached under the bench for a wooden box I had not seen and placed it in front of Liina with the declarative punctuation of a person who knows when an object will do more good than any sentence. Inside was a little metal plate with a seam like a river, like the line on Liina’s wrist, a piece of something that had obviously once been part of a larger gentleness. There were screw holes that had not complained. There was a tiny smear of dried glue like a touch left and forgotten. “It fell from somewhere,” Aila said, not moving her voice above the sea’s volume. “From something you carried or something we carried or something the house believed you belonged to. You put it in the box because it did not want to be swept.”

We walked to the harbor later, because in towns like this there are only two directions worth walking: toward the water and away. The pier had the same notches it always has because habits are more stubborn than storms. A plastic ring hung where it must hang, and the rope attached to it was new in the way rope shows off when it has not yet lived through a winter. Arto walked behind us, not as a shadow, not as a guard, but as a demonstration of how to be near without crowding. He touched the railing lightly with his knuckles, the old sailor’s way of greeting a thing that has saved you or will. Liina stopped at the place where the boards bend a little under the weight of three people standing together, and she stood very straight and put her hands not on the rail but at her sides, fingers open as if showing the air she had brought nothing to steal. I did not take her hand because this was not a time for two. The water made its sound, and memory did what it wanted, which was not to return gracefully or not at all but to go forward in small enthusiastic steps and then sit down tired and then resume. I watched her face do the small passages it had taught me: a window opening, a door being checked twice, a drawer stuck, a drawer sliding suddenly easily all the way out.

“When I fell,” she said, finally, and I had to remind my heart to behave because that sentence is greedy in every language, “I was not surprised at the speed. I remember that. The speed was honest. The cold surprised me because it put such a hand on my mouth. But I was not surprised by the falling.” She turned slightly so that I could hear without intruding; Arto had stopped a distance away to stare at nothing with intensity, which is what men of his kind do when they are being careful. “I think before I left,” she went on, and the word left put its coat on politely, “before I left here, I had practiced falling. Not from piers but from names. From rooms. I think I learned the speed of it.” She looked at her wrist then, and pressed two fingers to the seam like someone checking a pulse at a place doctors have not inspected yet, and smiled to herself in a way that made the wind behave better for a moment. “I have edges, Urse,” she said without asking me to agree. “Not sharp ones. Necessary ones. Maybe they were put in by love. Maybe by accident. Maybe by me.”

We did not rush to pack the day with discoveries because the day was already full of being itself. We sat on a bench with peeling paint and ate the bread we had brought because appetite is one of the names you can call home. A boy fished with conviction and no success, and each time he cast his line he whispered something into the water the way supplicants whisper in temples when they do not want to disturb the god’s nap. A woman walked past and said Aila’s name like a password, and Aila answered without turning, and that is how communities function: by calling each other into being at the appropriate distance. When we rose, Arto handed Liina a key that was not to anything, not anymore, the old brass kind that feels like news in the palm, and he said, “You left this not under the mat but on the mat as if offering it back to the door. It is rude to refuse an object with that much courage,” and she put it in her pocket and did not say thank you because we had three days of thanks to equalize.

We slept that night in a room at the harbor boardinghouse under a picture of a ship that had clearly never been as clean in real water as it had been for the painter. The sheets smelled like the phrase good laundry. The wall was thin and we heard someone laugh in a language I did not try to identify, and Liina lay on her back and recited our drawer of verbs in a whisper, leaving a pause after Return as if taking attendance. “What comes after Return?” she asked into the ceiling, and I considered our private drawer and the hospital’s public one and Salla’s endless inventory of remedies and my mother’s shoebox of photographs and the lemon tree that had learned to be a sun indoors. “We could try Learn and not be ashamed of needing it,” I said, and she made the small affirmative hum that I had come to think of as my best grade. “We could also choose Forgive and see if it travels well,” she added, and then she reached across the demonstration of clean white between us and placed her hand on my shoulder in the place where the seam of my own body has always insisted, collarbone and doubt and pride, and we slept as if sleep had been scheduled for us by someone competent.

The next morning Aila sent us away with a bag of small impossible kindnesses—bread we had already proven we liked, a jar with a folded label that said Salt in a confident hand, and a piece of smoked fish wrapped like a secret—and she touched Liina’s cheek with exactly two fingers as a woman might bless a tile before laying it. “If you stay, you will be made into stories,” she said, not as a threat and not as a promise. “If you go, you will be made into stories,” and I scribbled the sentence onto my ticket because some days you have to let the world write itself on you, too. Arto walked with us as far as the corner where wind decides whether to be a guest or a host, and he stopped and held out his hand to me in the way of a man who is ready to agree that a stranger has become some kind of cousin through the lazy marriage of circumstance. “Take her back to your shelves,” he said, not unkind, and then to Liina, without searching for my approval, “Bring back your hands when you feel like it. The jars will not punish you for making them wait.” She nodded, the little captain’s nod, and I had to do something with my own hands so I put them in my pockets and found there the tickets to the ferry from a month ago and the little paper tulip Salla had thrust upon me, and I laughed silently because that day had decided to be literal.

On the train home the sky played at being many paintings in one hour—gray watercolor over an ink line of trees, an acrylic patch where sun tried a trick and then withdrew, a pencil sketch of distant barns that looked like sentences unfinished. Liina leaned her head against the window and instead of sleeping she watched our reflection the way you watch a stranger on public transport when you are trying to decide if they have chosen their coat because of function or memory. “I liked Aila’s singing scold,” she said after a long time, and I agreed because the world is better when someone tells you how to sit and also offers you soup. “And I like that he did not ask me to be Helmi,” she added without turning, and her voice had that careful evenness she uses when she is placing something on a shelf that will make the room truer. “I can be a room with more than one name on the buzzer,” she said, and I found myself grinning at the window like a person who has just solved a riddle no one else was working on.

Back in Tammela, the stairwell did its good hum and the neighbor had pinned up a notice for a missing glove as if it were a person; we stood reading its description with straight faces because it is important to behave for rituals. The lemon tree had made a new small leaf in our absence, and the rosemary had decided not to die that week purely out of spite. We set the bag on the table and relabeled hunger for the pleasure of it. In the process, Liina brushed her wrist against the edge of the drawer and hissed a small breath, and we both saw the thin seam catch light like a fish turning. It was not open, it was not anything theatrical, it was simply honest in a way we had decided in advance would not undo us. I took her hand and kissed the soft inside of it in the language we had not yet labeled, and she laughed and told me I was ridiculous in the tone people use right before they decide to let themselves be, too.

It would have been so narratively satisfying if the next day everything proceeded like a diagram, if memory came in neat squares and we checked them off as if completing a respectable form. Instead, Monday’s light was ungenerous and the buses were late and the hospital seemed to have put itself on inside out. A man shouted at no one in particular in the lobby and we all behaved as if the building did not echo. A delivery of oranges exploded into three different departments and I found one rolling under a bench hours later like a bright stowaway. Salla had a headache and no patience for jokes about it; she barked at me affectionately and then gave me half her sandwich with the air of a judge merciful despite the law. I moved among patients with a competence I wished belonged to me and not just to my coat; at one point I found myself standing at the window in a corridor no one confessed to owning and watching a woman in a pink hat argue with a patch of sunlight, and it was the most honest conversation I had seen all day.

Eero found me there and handed me a printout and one of those small square chocolates that hospital vending machines sell as if time can be sweetened. “People say that when memory returns it is like rain,” he said, leaning shoulder to wall as if he had been born in corridors, “but sometimes it is like hail, loud and inconsiderate and not immediately helpful,” and I looked at the printout and understood none of it except that he had meant to hand me a piece of courage disguised as cardiology. “Hail I can sort,” I said, and he nodded and made a face because he was about to tell me something not strictly medical and wanted me to blame him less. “I saw your Mira,” he said, and I waited because my face enjoys doing a thing that exasperates nurses. “She is wearing both earrings,” he finished, and my laugh startled a passing porter in a good way.

When I came home, there was a new box on Liina’s table with no label waiting like an invitation at a party you had not checked yes to. Inside, a ferry deck—not a faithful copy of any ferry we had known, but the idea of one, boards that were too perfectly aligned for real life, a railing at a slight yet deliberate wrong angle, a sky you could remove and replace if you wanted to. On the deck, glued with that invisible almost-shy glue she used when letting objects believe they were being themselves, were two small paper figures, not wire this time, not paint, just folded planes and the suggestion of shoulders. They stood at an immodest distance from each other, closer than we would have placed them yesterday, and one had a tiny red strip tied around where a neck would be, and the other had a square of gray shading where a hand might be if the light behave. I stood and looked at the box for so long that my back protested, and when Liina came in from the balcony with her hands damp from scolding the lemon tree for thirsting at inappropriate hours, she set her palm in the center of my spine and pressed gently, a correction she had earned the right to make. “We are allowed to tell the sea that it cannot have every chapter,” she said without drama, and I allowed myself to take her sentence as a prescription and not a philosophy for once.

That night, instead of labels, we wrote sentences and did not tape them anywhere. We wrote them to be true just long enough to sit with. I wrote I will not panic when the hum stops and then scratched not out and replaced it with I will learn to listen differently. She wrote I am the room and the person who hangs a coat in it and then added I am the coat and we laughed the way you laugh when you are too pleased with your own cleverness to pretend otherwise. We lay on the floor with the window bare and the lights off and the city let us hear its honest noises: a neighbor laughing as if to release pressure, a scooter being a mosquito, the soft car noise that only ever sounds like a river in the distance, a train horn that is always both departure and arrival to someone. Before sleep, she turned and pressed her mouth to the place on my shoulder blade where I had always imagined an invisible hinge, and she whispered all three names—hers and the one Arto had brought and mine—and it did not feel like choosing, it felt like inventory.

The seam at her wrist, that pale mapped road, a geographer’s delight, began to fade as the week softened, not disappearing, not surrendering, simply adjusting itself to the light we had decided to prefer. Sometimes, washing dishes, I would see it catch the afternoon the way a river shows where the sun has hung itself to dry, and I would feel both gratitude and indignation because the body keeps secrets and tells them and does not ask for our editorial notes. Once, in the hospital, a woman reached for my hand in the exact gesture Liina sometimes made when she wanted a word passed silently, and I took it and she pressed a small thing into my palm—a button, old, mother-of-pearl—with a thread through it, and said, “I’m paying you with this,” and when I tried to give it back she refused, and Salla, witnessing the exchange, declared, “Now you have all the currency required,” and for an hour my pockets felt briefly like graceland.

On a late afternoon that could have been evening if you were feeling indulgent, my mother called with the small catastrophe of a leaking pipe and the large catastrophe of a sentence you could hear behind it that said, I am alone with this, and I told her I would come Saturday and bring a man who would not overcharge her, and after I hung up I found Liina labeling a new drawer Serious with a neatness that made me want to cross the room and kiss her hands. “We can go together,” she said before I asked, and then, with the solemnity of someone negotiating with their own weather, “You go into the crawl space. I will pass you tools. I will say clever things in the tone of an old mechanic,” and she proceeded to imitate Aila flawlessly and then Arto’s brevity, and I laughed and leaned into the kitchen counter as if it could assist my ribs in the matter of joy.

On the way to bed that night I noticed on the hall floor beneath her window a new small glint, not metal this time, not something my fingers recognized, a sliver of clear plastic like a scale from a fish you did not mean to catch. I picked it up and held it to the light and it shone with the modesty of maintenance; I could not tell if it had fallen from a plant or a box or from the night we had carried back from the coast. I put it in our jar of misplaced things because that was what we had learned to do with pieces that insisted on being themselves while declining to be introductions. We would shake the jar when we needed weather. We would hold it when we needed proof. We would listen when we needed rain.

Chapter 9 was the week the windows learned to open without complaint, the hinges remembering they were meant for motion and not simply for holding everything in place. It started with a breeze that smelt faintly like wet metal and birch sap, and the city, like a patient released from a cast, put weight down carefully and then with more confidence. In the mornings, buses exhaled less steam and apologized less for being late. The lemon tree made a small, exuberant forest of pale new leaves, each the precise green that people try and fail to paint, and the rosemary, which had spent the winter arguing with the concept of endurance, lifted its thin arms as if having decided not to die was worth the theatrical gesture. On the fridge, our drawer of verbs had become a quiet argument we held with ourselves daily, and I found myself touching Return with a fingertip as if pushing a bell, only to turn and find that Learn had been nudged forward in its place, Liina’s humor lingering in the air like cardamom. The jar of misplaced things gained two screws, a paperclip bent into a question mark, the clear plastic scale that refused to explain itself, and a bead that had once been red and had decided to be something else now, and when we shook the jar after dinner the sound was like rain practicing.

We went to my mother’s because the pipe under her sink had decided time was a river it wanted to join, and because she will not say help until she has already mopped twice and the mop sighs in a way that makes you ashamed of younger versions of yourself. The train to Nokia was full of Sunday errands dressed as leisure, and we sat among bags that contained carrots and laundry detergent and a rolled carpet with a stain whose story had been negotiated into a family myth. My mother greeted us at the door with her sleeves rolled and her chin set in that degree of determination that once made me eat mushrooms without complaint and once made my father rehang a door at nine at night because the angle offended her. She looked at Liina and said her name the way careful hands test the weight of a bowl from a cupboard they haven’t opened in years—she had practiced it, and the practice had made it kind. “I will make tea for after,” she declared, and then, as if remembering a lesson from a woman with a singing scold, “And for during, if the pipe behaves like a person.”

The crawlspace was exactly the animal I remembered—dusty, narrow-minded, smelling like a museum of small rodents—but I slid in with the bravado of an adolescent showing off on old home turf. Liina knelt by the opening and passed me tools with the solemn efficiency of a surgical nurse, and because she is a better actor than I am brave, she imitated Aila’s under-the-breath humming, little admonishments addressed to bolts that refused to cooperate and to the wrench that thought too much of itself. “Now the cloth,” she said, and then, with that tiny private smile that never quite reaches her mouth’s corners, “No, the blue, not the white, we don’t want the pipe thinking it’s being forgiven.” My mother hovered, a good hovering learned over years of not wanting to parent a grown child but unable to neglect the muscle memory of concern, and when I swore, once, because old screws have tempers, she laughed a laugh that had less edge than it once did. The leak gave up with a reluctant gulp, and I lay on my back under the sink and stared at the graceful curve of the trap and thought about how blessed it is that some parts of the world are named after their behavior.

After, we sat at her kitchen table with mugs sweating rings into the brown paint that looks like toast, and my mother produced ginger biscuits from a tin so old it had acquired the right to be a relative. She asked Liina questions the way cautious people ask dogs their names—slowly, with belief in the goodness of a reply, and prepared to accept an alternative. “Was your mother the kind who sang the same song on Mondays?” she asked, then smiled at her own clumsy reach and waved it away, adding, “There are mothers who do that,” and Liina, who has learned how to gather a person’s intention with both hands and spare them from their own awkwardness, took the question and made it a gift. “I remember a woman singing on odd days,” she said quietly, “and the geometry of the kitchen when she moved, and a bowl with a chip that we learned to love because it was honest, and a wooden spoon that had its own weather.” My mother nodded as if the answer had been as good as any truth she could have demanded and then made a small noise in her throat that meant she would be correcting the placement of the sugar bowl in the next minute and couldn’t bear to confess it.

The repair left me with an ache in my shoulder that was punishment for having a body that forgets its limits when loved ones are watching, and on the way back to the station we stopped by the river that tries to be a river but is almost always a polite, brown argument. On the path, a boy threw stones with that careful calculation that means his father is a fisherman or an engineer, and his mother stood with her hands in the pockets of a coat that had known better days, and she looked at us and nodded in the ancient trans-species greeting of mothers in public, and Liina nodded back like someone returning a pass at a game she did not know the rules for but refused to disdain. In the train car, we recognized three faces and pretended not to, as is our duty. Liina leaned her head on my shoulder and counted under her breath the trees that still wore their winter shape, and at one of the brief stops between nowhere and someone’s childhood she touched my hand and said, “When your mother said my name, it grew,” and I thought how names do that when they are used for carrying instead of for pinning.

At the hospital, the week unfolded with the brisk illogic of spring. The man with Korsakoff had a day when he remembered the exact way his wife had salted cucumber slices, and Salla, standing at his shoulder, described the crunch of a perfect cuke as if narrating a poem, and he cried without tragedy and then asked us if we had ever noticed how the light on the floor in the afternoons looks like a promise and a warning at once. Jarmo, who takes pride in being a weather system that never delivers rain at inconvenient hours, told us, with his eyebrows instead of with words, that he had become a grandfather, and I watched him try to keep his face obedient and fail for half a second, and I forgave him for every grunt he had ever issued as a form of punctuation. Eero brought me a journal article on something new that had the suddenly archaic word dawn in the title, and we both appreciated the audacity of the metaphor, and he unwrapped a potato-shaped rock from tissue paper that I had, without ceremony, placed on his desk on Monday, and he laughed the way men laugh when they want to tell you they are pleased and that they will never make this kind of thing a habit.

Mira at the front desk had grown her hair two centimeters in a week the way only young women do, and when I handed her the matching earring tied in paper with string, an act delayed by interruptions since everything, she pressed her hand to her chest in a gesture so theatrical we both had to grin as if someone were photographing us for a manual on how to be grateful in public. “It came home,” she said again, as if by repeating it she could normalize the flood of small kindnesses into a schedule all of us could keep. Later that afternoon a man threw an orange in the corridor and it travelled in a perfect line past the nurse’s station, and Salla, without looking up from a chart, moved her foot so it rolled into the corner where stray oranges go to reconsider their careers, and the whole world briefly made a sense I could have bottled and prescribed.

Back at home, the neighbor with lipstick and a laundry basket fell on the stairs in the most ordinary way, the way everyone who lived there had fallen once and chosen to remember as a lesson and never as a story. The sound was the precise sound of a knee acknowledging its age, and I was there because my body had learned the building’s noises like vocabulary. I was turning the corner with a bag of potatoes and a stethoscope in my coat pocket that made me feel like a caricature, and Liina was behind me, trying to decide whether rosemary prefers to be scolded in the morning or afternoon. We did the thing we always do: we became efficient without showing off. I set the bag down and went to one knee with the formality of a proposal. The old woman hissed through her teeth and did not pretend she had not. “I told you,” she said to the banister as if it had been rude, “I told you I know your tricks,” and Liina, who respects both inanimate and animate dignity, waited until breath had decided to be polite again and then crouched, hands visible and at a distance, and addressed the woman the way you address pain when you don’t want it to feel challenged. “Let us be gentle with the next few minutes,” she said, softly, the way a conductor asks the strings to come in, and the old woman made a face that indicated she would not be charmed but would comply for reasons unrelated to charm. We improvised a bandage from the clean dishcloth an upstairs neighbor handed down like a blessing on a clothesline; we refused to stand the old woman until she had supervised our plan to stand her; we laughed when she declared our hands too warm; and because the building is a village, a man from three doors down offered a chair with a back that didn’t wobble and Salla’s cousin’s boy, who happens to live on our floor and pretends to practice his trumpet in the afternoons, brought his trumpet case as if an instrument has a right to watch courage.

That night, after the eggs she brought us in a plastic bag that had once carried celery, the old woman knocked on our door and gave us a story because she was the kind of person who knows the exchange rate. “When I was sixteen,” she said, leaning in as if the hallway air would steal her nouns, “I fell from a dock and no one saw and the water had no manners and I became a very quiet person for a while,” and I watched Liina stand perfectly still in that way she has when the world tries to be big all at once and chooses instead to be exact. “We are better at being quiet when we learn how to make noise later,” Liina said when the woman had gone and the eggs sat on the counter like promises we had not yet cracked, and I put my hand on her wrist without looking and felt the seam, the not-seam, the mapped line, and it was there and it was not an emergency.

In the evenings, the boxes multiplied into a form of life. Liina began to thread movement into them without betraying their stillness. A tram bell that could, if you persuaded it, speak in the miniature; a paper curtain that lifted when you leaned near as if acknowledging your breath; a tiny clock with a paper face and hands too honest to point at a wrong time without apology; a door that opened no more than a centimeter and showed you, when you dared to look, only a coat hanging like a refusal easy with itself. She taught me to cut cardboard along its bones instead of against them, and I learned to listen when glue speaks and when paint pretends not to. I made a box that looked like my mother’s living room the winter after my father left, and I could not tell if it was a cruelty or a kindness to make the chair that had held his weight across so many Sundays, and Liina stood beside me and said, “Let’s put a book on the chair,” and so we did, and the book made the room ours in a way no man could unmake.

A letter came in a real envelope with stamps that had been decided upon by someone with respect for birds: an invitation from a community center that my mother frequents, asking if a certain local artist who builds small rooms would consider displaying a few pieces at the spring open evening, an event that boasts coffee in weak cups and gratitude unfiltered by fashion. Mira knew a woman who knew a boy who had a grandmother who played cards with the librarian in the same room where my mother, years ago, had danced to a scratchy polka that rearranged her future, and thus the invitation found us. I handed it to Liina with the flourish of a magician producing a rabbit he is not afraid of, and she read it twice and then once more, and then she put it on the table under the sugar bowl that does not move without permission and said, “We could give the town empty rooms it recognizes,” and I understood it as both an artistic statement and a humanitarian one. We chose four boxes and then five and then six because restraint is not always a virtue, and she labeled their undersides not with their proper names but with the words they were trying to carry: Wait, Begin, Leave, Return, Name, Forgive.

Before we went to the community center, we rehearsed carrying the boxes up and down our own stairs because theatricality, even when performed for one’s neighbors, is a test of joints. We threaded ribbon through holes we punched in cardboard as handles, and our building smelled like paper and glue and that slight chemical smell masterpieces always carry until the world wears it off. The day itself was a comedy of small logistics and large tenderness. My mother met us outside the center and took one box immediately without being asked, as if to say, I will help you carry the weight that made you, and Liina handed her a piece labeled Corridor and watched my mother’s face as the old woman walked it in like a baby. The room had been decorated by people who understand that bunting is an apology for white walls; from the stage, a child read a poem about a duck with an authority that made men uncomfortable. We set the boxes on a long table with a cloth that had seen better winters and we stepped back, as you must, and we did not hover or explain. People approached the boxes the way they approach religious relics or free samples—wary, then greedy, then embarrassed, then grateful. They looked at the tiny bowl with apples and murmured the names of people they had fed; they tilted their heads to see if the rug was the green they had in their own kitchens; they recognized the stairwell banister’s worn spot and reached out to touch it without touching at all; a man in a sensible jacket began to tell a story about the day he met his wife in a corridor lined with coats that smelled like rain, and then he stopped and looked at the ceiling as if it held the rest of the sentence in a jar.

My mother moved among the people like a woman introducing her friends to her other friends, and when she came to the ferry deck she did not flinch, because she is the kind of person who believes in practicing your expressions ahead of your life. She touched the paper rail with two fingers and then pressed her hand to Liina’s back in that domestic way that says I would like to lay a claim without making you wear a collar. Later, when the coffee was half-strength and the buns had chosen their successful companions, an old man with a suit that had seen weddings and funerals equally came and set a button in the lid of our jar, a tiny offering in a room that does not require taxes, and he said, to the air, “I had this in my coat for years as an argument I never had to use,” and Liina, who collects these sentences for her own weather, nodded and said thank you as if the word were more than one.

On our way home, the wind negotiated with our ears sullenly, and we walked in a way that did not declare victory but accepted our hour. Liina’s wrist brushed my sleeve, and I felt the seam through fabric, not because it had raised itself but because I had learned where to find it even in the dark, and the knowledge was not a burden. She said her name once, the one Arto had brought in a careful voice like a dish you don’t put down hard, and then mine twice, testing the echoes under the bridge we passed, and then she lifted both our hands and, ridiculous as it would have seemed to anyone driving past, counted our fingers in the way people count treasure, slow, respectful, certain there will be enough.

Then the city did what cities do and reminded us of other people’s weather. A boy had been brought to our ward because the world had put its mouth on him and shaken hard, and his mother sat with the stubborn patience that women wear when the doctors in their coats say we shall see and mean it, and in the break room Salla bit into an apple with needless violence because she does not have room for more stories and needed one with only one character. Jarmo grunted in a way that made me reach for his shoulder without thinking and then withdraw because he does not always want to be made into a mammal. Eero stopped me in the corridor and said, with awkward bravery that made him younger and older at once, “I am afraid of forgetting people before they leave,” and I told him the truth, because he deserved it, which is that we forget and then we remember the shape if not the color, and that both are honest and neither is betrayal. He handed me the potato-rock I had given him, and I pressed it back into his hand and said, “We keep the right things,” and he said, “We learn to,” and we smiled as if we had invented competence.

Some nights in that week I startled awake to the exact sound of the sea I had not lived beside, and for a moment I did not know if the water was outside or inside or in the jar we had begun to shake when the apartment needed weather, and then I would hear the small familiar cough of the radiator and the soft drawing-in of our building as it slept, and I would look over and Liina would be on her back with her hands folded on her stomach like a woman being shown a dress she is not sure she loves yet, and I would put my hand on the midline of her chest and feel the good hum, the steady machine that is older than all our engines, and I would whisper our names because it had become a habit and a law and a comfort. Once, half-asleep, she whispered back a string of words that belonged to no drawer, a private litany: window, spoon, light, lemon, hand, keep, and I smiled into my pillow because that is how people who do not believe in prayers pray.

The seam faded and returned like a tide that is a rumor rather than a fact, a pale path that sometimes declared itself and sometimes hid under the day like a secret that had no malice and no wish to be entertained. We learned not to perform for it. We learned to exist next to it the way you exist next to a neighbor’s old car that starts on the second try and not the first unless it is Sunday. Once in the shower, where honesty is a lazy fog, she stood with her hand lifted and let water run along the ridge the way rain finds the shallow rut in a city and maps it, and she laughed at the tickle, and then, without looking down, said, “Do you think there was ever a me without an edge?” and I said, because I was rinsing soap from my eyes and had no hope of lying convincingly, “No, not a one worth loving.”

The night before the community center wanted the boxes back for fear of someone who loved them too hard, we set them all on the floor and lay among them like two figures in a painting where perspective is both ambitious and wrong, and we talked, because talking has become our way to hold the day by the corners before folding it. She told me that sometimes she thinks she is a map with one river drawn too dark, and sometimes she thinks she is a blueprint for a room where the windows have been left out on purpose so that someone else will remember to add them, and sometimes she thinks she is simply a person with plants, and that last thought gives her the calm of an ordinary day. I told her the hospital had a smell that changes with the moon even though I do not believe in that, and that sometimes I stare at the wall behind Salla’s station because the paint there has a line like a coastline and I need coasts even when they are paint. We chose Forgive from the drawer and stood with it in our hands for a while without putting it anywhere, and then we tucked it under the salt again like a recipe we are not ready to attempt. Out the window, the street shone with the polite slick of evening rain, and the neighbor tuned his bicycle with his little radio keeping time, and in our jar, the metal and the plastic and the bead shifted delicately when the bus went by as if the city were whispering, just for us, that it was not in charge and that we were permitted to listen anyway.

On Friday I walked into the ward behind a deliveryman carrying a cardboard box with hospitals printed all over it and expected to turn left, and instead Jarmo put his hand up in a gesture that might, on another face, have been a plea. “Come see,” he said, and he did not grunt, and I followed him to a window that looked at nothing any architect ever meant to exist, and there, in the practical rectangle of the sky framed by the ugliest part of the building, danced a pair of green lights, not aurora, not anything more mystical than a construction crane’s argument with a wind I could not feel, and I laughed out loud and did not apologize, and Salla laughed too because she is righteous but not humorless, and Eero looked as if he had been granted permission to be younger, and for a minute we were too human and then we resumed our work because that is our religion.

That evening, home before dark because we had chosen to be, we ate potatoes and herring and bread that fought back in a way I have learned to love, and Liina put her foot on my knee and read telegram-style headlines from the small newspaper my mother insists on sending me by post so that I will not forget ink, and we muttered remarks appropriate to people who pretend to keep up, and then she reached over and slipped the potato-shaped rock into my hand without looking up, and I raised my eyebrows at her and she shrugged and said, “It wanted to be held by both of us,” and I believed her because some objects do speak and some days you are required to listen. When we went to bed, she folded her hands on her stomach again and then moved them, deliberately, to the space between us and rested them there, open, a gesture of faith you can miss if you are not trained to reach. I put mine in hers, fingers sliding into that rightness we do not always deserve, and we lay like that until the hum of the building became tide and the tide became hum and the day agreed, at last, to leave us.

Chapter 10 was the week the city tied ribbons to its own wrists and promised to behave. Vappu balloons appeared overnight like a flock that had not asked anyone’s permission to land, students wore their caps with the earnest swagger that makes me forgive them every spring, and the kiosks began to sell sima that tasted like a childhood I did not have but chose to borrow. The wind learned to play with crepe paper, then apologized to no one when it tore it. On Saturday morning we walked to the square where the brass band rehearsed the same three bars twice as long as necessary, and old men in army jackets stood with feet apart, arms folded, assuming the pose of benevolent municipal oversight. Liina took it in the way she takes in most holidays, like a language lesson whose teacher has decided joy is grammar. She asked me what exactly we were celebrating and I admitted that in Finland we sometimes celebrate the possibility of celebrating and count the rest as extra. She grinned into her paper cup and declared that sima tastes like an idea that went right.

In our kitchen the lemon tree had finally flowered, tiny star mouths open to a sweetness so intense it made the air feel deliberate. When I leaned over the blossoms, the scent was a story pretending to be a smell, and Liina put her fingertip to one flower and pulled back as if she’d been told a secret she wasn’t sure she deserved. “I remember lemon somewhere else,” she said in the tone you use with a skittish bird, “not the taste—the authority,” and I nodded because some things in a kitchen tell you what to do and some wait to be instructed. We moved the pot an inch toward the window, the way you move a chair to accommodate a guest who will sit only if the angle is right.

At the hospital, Salla enacted her annual Vappu tyranny and brought paper streamers and a plate of donuts that she would not call munkki because she enjoys pretending we are above such provincial loyalties. She draped the nurses’ station as if it were a bride she thought might bolt and then told me to stand still so she could tie a ribbon to my buttonhole, a favor that made Jarmo watch the whole procedure with eyebrows attempting modesty. Eero passed through with a bottle of sima from his grandmother, his face declaring that he knew it was childish and also that he was pleased to be the one providing it, and he said to me, in the manner of a man stepping into metaphor because he cannot help himself, that memory this week was a park bench in sunshine—people sat longer than they meant to and left something of themselves behind on the slats. Our man with Korsakoff found himself more certain of a story about a parade in 1973, his hands describing greater flags than the hospital has ever flown, and Salla, who knows how to applaud without humiliating, kept time on the counter with her fingernail.

In the middle of the week, a letter came like a small drumbeat. An envelope addressed in the straight hand that has begun to belong to us arrived with a ferry stamp and inside, on a piece of card cut from something else to be useful again, was a sentence only Arto could have written: The jars forgive delays, and under it, fixed with a piece of tape that had once belonged to a box of mandarins, a tiny metal bird with a copper beak, no bigger than a coin. We set the bird on the windowsill between rosemary and lemon, and it looked the way a suggestion looks when you don’t yet know if it is a promise. Liina touched its beak with the back of her knuckle as if it might peck if startled and said, “We should make a room with a window that opens,” and I agreed, which is to say I found the scissors and the good glue.

The jar of misplaced things acquired a reputation and began to recruit. The neighbor with lipstick knocked and brought a safety pin bent into a triangle, telling us she had worn it on her blouse for a week by mistake, thinking it a brooch, and when she realized she had been fooled she loved it more and decided to contribute it to the cause of general misplacement. I added a tram ticket that had clung to the inside of my pocket as if for warmth; Liina, without comment, dropped in the clear plastic scale we had found weeks ago under her window. When we shook the jar sometimes, the pieces argued kindly, a private weather with its own calendar. We didn’t solve them. We didn’t name them beyond their nature. We let the sound coat the room like the noise rain makes in a bowl outside a kitchen door.

We decided to host a small evening because it felt like the right spell to cast on a week that wanted to be noisier than we did. Not a party—our building would mutiny against the word—but a gathering that allowed our rooms to meet the people we kept using their names for. We wrote invitations in the corner of other conversations: to Salla, handed with a donut to legitimize the bribe; to the old woman with lipstick and excellent knees when they are behaving; to Mira, who came with the proper apology for leaving her desk and with an armful of serviettes because she cannot resist being the sort of person who arrives with paper; to the boy who practices trumpet who promised out loud he would not play and whose eyes begged us to ask him to. Jarmo raised his eyebrows into what passed for assent and muttered something about not staying late, which in his dialect means help me leave gracefully.

The afternoon of the gathering, the building reminded me that any plan must prove itself under pressure. The fire alarm tested itself in the most theatrical way at four, and every door opened and every person obeyed the choreography we all pretend to disdain. In the staircase, pajamas from the fifth floor exchanged significant looks with suits from the second; someone held their cat like a trophy; the neighbor across from us stood on the landing with a dish towel over her shoulder as if she had planned to be photographed as a civilian hero. Liina stood very straight, hands at her sides, her face arranged for a test she had not scheduled. For a moment I watched her move through confusion like a swimmer through a cold patch—sharp intake, strong strokes, resumed breath. In the slow shuffle of bodies, she looked at me and said my name in the tone that has saved both of us from many small drownings, and when, ten minutes later, we were all released back into our qualified lives, she put her palm on the kitchen light switch and whispered thank you to it the way some people thank a reluctant horse.

The seam at her wrist made a brief claim on the day as she reached for the glasses on the top shelf. It caught the late light, declared itself without dramatics, and she held her hand in the air for an extra beat, examining it as if it had raised its hand in class. “It is different in spring,” she observed, not asking for confirmation so much as acknowledging the season’s effect on the map of the body. “Everything is,” I said, and then, because I had meant to say it less carelessly, I added, “We are kinder to some lines when the light changes,” and she nodded with that serious humor that saves me from myself.

People came carrying the small unnecessarys that make any gathering feel deliberate. Salla’s tulip paper flowers survived a bus ride and an argument with a child on the stairs whose mother apologized and then refused to apologize again; she installed them in our lemon pot with the gravitas of a florist at a coronation. The old woman arrived with eggs again and a story she announced she would earn the right to tell by helping wash dishes later. Mira brought a white bowl that looked like every bowl I like best and set it on the table as if it were a guest. The trumpet boy, to his credit, did not bring his trumpet, but he did bring his case, and when we stared at him in the unified curiosity of adults who remember being impossible, he said, “It is good for sitting on,” and he was right. Jarmo stood near the door in the way of men who wish to be the first to leave and then forgot to leave. We placed the boxes on the low bookcase, not to show them off but so that the room could read them over our shoulders, and then we did not make speeches because our building would never forgive us that.

There was soup—there is always soup when I do not know how to name a day—and bread that fought back just enough to keep conversation honest. At some point, in the middle of an argument between Salla and Mira about whether notices in stairwells should be signed with a name to prevent anarchy, a small hailstorm of memory hit Liina. It came with no warning beyond the stilling of her hand on the back of the chair, a familiar hush that I respect now with a courtesy I did not have when all this began. Her eyes shifted, that narrow adjustment you can miss if you are not trained, and she looked at me as a person looks at a map that has changed itself. “Who are you?” she said, with an open curiosity that did not bruise, and the room gently, expertly, continued in a lower register around us because kindness is also a sound. I answered with our oldest ritual, not performing, not pleading. “I’m Urse,” I said, in a voice I use when reading the directions printed too small on the back of medicine, “I live across the hall; we are in my kitchen; your lemon tree is being cheeky; Salla has tied ribbons to things that did not ask for ribbons,” and at the word lemon her mouth tugged toward the smell, at across the hall her eyes softened into recognition, and at ribbons she rolled her eyes toward Salla with a complicity that reassured me more than anything. “Yes,” she said, a simple assent, and reached for my hand not as a rescue but as a test of physics, and it held. The storm passed—this time a quick percussion instead of the long weather system—and when later the old woman told her dock story again, she listened like a person taking notes on survival and stood to do the dishes with sleeves rolled and no fuss.

After people left the way decent people do—reluctantly and with their hands full of washing to justify coming back—we sat at the table and looked at the mess with the pride of a battlefield commander whose only casualties were serviettes and one heroic spoon. The trumpet case remained as a bench because the boy had forgotten it by design and would need an excuse to return. On the fridge, the drawer of verbs had been disturbed by the draft from the open window and two had shifted in a pose I could not have staged better: Return leaning against Begin as if whispering. Liina stood and moved the magnets by only the width of a coin and then stepped back and looked at me with that steady, cataloging gaze. “Should we be a room with one buzzer?” she asked, neither flirting nor performing nor apologizing, and I did not need to ask which of the drawers to choose. I stood, went to the hall table, picked up the small silver key that had lived alone in a dish for years, and brought it to her on my palm like an object offered at a temple. “We can be a room with a buzzer and an open door,” I said, “and labels we can peel off and move when the light tells us to.”

We did not pack that night because moving for the sake of moving is a game for other seasons. We did a smaller, more honest thing. She took two mugs from my cupboard and placed them next to the kettle in her kitchen, so the morning would find its way without directions.
