I took her spare sweater, the one with a snag I admire and a smell I would recognize in a crowd of storms, and hung it on my chair back as if it had always been a resident. We put our toothbrushes in the same cup and laughed at the domesticated intimacy of it, then quieted because some rituals require a soft step. Above the sink, the window reflected our two faces side by side, tired, pleased, ordinary, and for a brief, indecently sentimental second I thought: we are a before picture I have always preferred to an after.

The next day I found myself telling Salla I would be late because I had to go to the registry office to procure a copy of a paper that would persuade the building’s super that two names can peacefully occupy a single small letterbox, and she widened her eyes and made the sign of the cross with two pens as if she were blessing a ship. “Take a photograph of the clerk,” she commanded, “because I want to see the face of the person who will hold your domesticity in a file,” and then, because she cannot help rescuing every moment from itself, she added, “Also take a sandwich; bureaucracy eats glucose.” At the office, a woman with hair that expressed nothing but competence took my form and stamped it with a sound like a minor magic trick; I like to watch stamps work, the way they correct the world with their own tidy thunder. She did not ask me to justify our arrangement. She did not ask me to produce evidence we were not a danger to the staircase. She gave me a paper that smelled faintly of ink and authority and wished me a good day with the exact neutrality that allowed me to believe she meant it.

On my way back, I stopped at the market hall and bought herring because I have become my mother but will not admit it until I have figured out how to season better than she does. I ran into Mira at the stall where women sell things you wish your grandparents had left you, and she showed me a stack of postcards from Turku that had been tied with string decades ago and had chosen to stay that way. On the top card, a ferry was caught in winter light like an animal mid-breath; I bought it, though I do not collect postcards, because there are days when sentimentality is simply gratitude with less training. In the hospital lobby, Eero stopped me and said, with an awkwardness he had earned the right to not be ashamed of, “I read something about the malleability of autobiographical memory and felt both lifted and scolded,” and I told him we had put two toothbrushes in one cup and he smiled as if I had offered him evidence for a paper he wanted to write and promised he would never write.

We built, that week, a box we had avoided building. It was labeled Clinic in Liina’s tidy hand, and on its tiny walls hung the posters I have stared at for years with affection and a reasonable amount of resentment—hand washing instructions with cartoon hands that never felt shame, a chart of flu symptoms that had been pointed at by too many bad days, a framed photograph of a lake disguised as a motivational message. The waiting chairs were too upright because that is how waiting chairs are. A little table held magazines made from folded newspaper strips, and we laughed with a little cruelty at our own accuracy. In one corner, we placed a miniature jar labeled Lost and did not fill it, trusting that the room would do that itself. When we had finished and sat looking at it with the concentrated pride of amateur sailors who have managed not to tip, Liina slid the clear plastic scale from the jar of misplaced things into the window frame and tilted it until the light decided to behave. The effect was absurdly real: a small, honest glare that made the room feel functional. “Now we can be seen without having to be perfect,” she said, and I reached across the table and touched the quick on her thumbnail with my thumb, a superstition I invented on the spot and refused to explain.

One morning, as spring overstepped and tried out summer’s habits, my mother telephoned and declared, without introduction, that she had decided to befriend the neighbor with knees because it was better than pretending to know nothing about each other’s groceries. “I brought her tulips,” she reported, “and she told me to label them, and I told her labeling flowers is nonsense and then I thought of your kitchen and I had to sit down,” and I laughed out loud in the corridor and a patient laughed at my laugh and then apologized, and we both waved our hands as if to shoo away the birds that make embarrassment into an art. I told my mother about the toothbrushes and she said, with that false boredom mothers manufacture for the sake of dignity, “Hmm,” and then, after a beat, “What is her favorite soup?” which in our family is another way of saying welcome.

In the evenings the city chose to pretend it was July for two hours and then sulked back into May, and we learned the opening dance of windows and blankets. We took the tram to the lake as a way of paying the day its due and sat on the rocks where older women in swimsuits talk as if every sentence is a chance to correct Darwin. An older man told us the exact water temperature and seemed disappointed when we did not stand and applaud his courage. A child asked his father if the lake had a password, and the father, without missing a beat, said it did but that the lake changed it daily, and the boy nodded, satisfied beyond reason. Liina took off her shoes and put her feet into the water until her legs decided they were made of a better metal than mine and then pulled them out with a hiss that made even the swans look as if they had been reminded to be careful. “I do not want to forget this specific cold,” she announced, and I made the unnecessary promise that neither of us would.

We received another note from Aila, this time on the back of a grocery list where someone had run out of butter too early in the week. She had cut her sentence to fit: The mouse is not back; the jars are haughty; we are still here. She had added a small drawing of a key in a hand that did not know it could draw and underlined still as if daring us to argue. Liina put the card inside the box labeled Workshop and for a day the whole apartment smelled like old wood and work and the particular safety you find in rooms where people know what to do with their hands. At night we lay with the window open and the lemon blossoms told us, without art, what kindness smells like, and in the dark she said, sleepily, as if reading out loud to see how the words felt in air, “I am Liina and once I was Helmi and some days I am a person with plants,” and I murmured, low, “And always you are the person with hands,” and she laughed into the pillow, the small muffled bell that marks my hours.

The seam on her wrist learned to be shy in full sun and bold under the kitchen light. Once in the shower she raised her arm and let water find the ridge and then tried to trap it there with a fingertip, making a tiny dam that taught us nothing about geology and everything about pleasure. “Edge,” she said, naming it the way a child names a pet that already knows it belongs, and I said, because I could and because we have learned to forgive ourselves for being obvious in private, “Stay.” We did not tell anyone about the name we gave a line on a wrist because some intimacies must be kept stupid and perfect or they will perform for company and lose their salaries.

On a Wednesday that felt like it had been improperly placed between two Fridays, the boy with the trumpet case came to retrieve it and did not bring his trumpet and still managed to play. He set the case down, thanked us with a sincerity I would have failed to muster at his age, and then asked, uninvited and therefore exactly correctly, if he could see the box labeled Tram. We lifted it down and set it on the table like a cake, and he peered at the tiny bell and pressed it with a fingernail and when it made the very small noise we had installed for ourselves, he looked up as if someone had told him a secret he could keep. “It’s better than the real one,” he announced gravely, and when we were done laughing we decided to interpret his pronouncement as praise and not a referendum on public transport.

On Friday night, I lay awake for a while the way you do when the day insists it has one more thing to say and you have promised it nothing. I thought about deadlines and the way some weeks arrive with little banners and parades and demand summary and others slip out the back door, content to have stitched themselves into your coat hem. I thought about the paper at the registry office and the way the clerk’s stamp had sounded like a door being shut kindly, and I thought about Arto’s copper-beaked bird and Aila’s grocery list and Jarmo’s scalpels of eyebrow and Salla’s ribbons that had survived children and wind and cynicism and still looked pleased with themselves. I thought about the small plastic scale now living in the clinic window in a box in our living room and the way light had obeyed it, and I laughed softly because the world delights in obeying things that don’t know the weight of their own orders.

Sleep came when I turned and put my hand on the exact tableland of Liina’s chest where her good hum is most confident. She rolled toward me with her practiced harbor docking and set her hand on my shoulder where the seam of me has always needed attention. In that soft almost-dream, she whispered my name and then, slow as if reading it off a bottle with a label she had drawn herself, she said, “Keep,” and I said, “Begin,” and then the building did its night noise, a distant train confessed and moved on, and somewhere a neighbor laughed as if rehearsing for summer, and we joined the hum we had decided was ours without asking anyone to prove it.
